review.title: Optimizing SPARQL Query Answering over OWL Ontologies
review.abstract: The SPARQL query language is currently being extended by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) with so-called entailment regimes. An entailment regime defines how queries are evaluated under more expressive semantics than SPARQLs standard simple entailment, which is based on subgraph matching. The queries are very expressive since variables can occur within complex concepts and can also bind to concept or role names. In this paper, we describe a sound and complete algorithm for the OWL Direct Semantics entailment regime. We further propose several novel optimizations such as strategies for determining a good query execution order, query rewriting techniques, and show how specialized OWL reasoning tasks and the concept and role hierarchy can be used to reduce the query execution time. For determining a good execution order, we propose a cost-based model, where the costs are based on information about the instances of concepts and roles that are extracted from a model abstraction built by an OWL reasoner. We present two ordering strategies: a static and a dynamic one. For the dynamic case, we improve the performance by exploiting an individual clustering approach that allows for computing the cost functions based on one individual sample from a cluster. We provide a prototypical implementation and evaluate the efficiency of the proposed optimizations. Our experimental study shows that the static ordering usually outperforms the dynamic one when accurate statistics are available. This changes, however, when the statistics are less accurate, e.g., due to nondeterministic reasoning decisions. For queries that go beyond conjunctive instance queries we observe an improvement of up to three orders of magnitude due to the proposed optimizations.

metadata.title: Optimizing SPARQL Query Answering over OWL Ontologies

sections.text: In this paper, we describe a solid and complete algorithm for the OWL Direct Semantics system. In addition, we propose several new optimizations, such as strategies for determining a good query execution order, query rewriting techniques, and show how specialized OWL reasoning tasks and the concept and role hierarchy can be used to reduce the execution time of Query Execution Time. To determine a good query execution order, we propose a cost-based model in which costs are based on information about instances of concepts and roles extracted from a model abstraction created by an OWL argumentator. We present two order strategies: a static and a dynamic one. In the dynamic case, we improve performance by using an individual cluster approach that enables the calculation of cost functions based on a single sample from a cluster. We provide a prototype implementation and evaluate the efficiency of proposed optimizations when statistical sequences are available, our statistical analysis shows that the exact sequence of the quantity is available.

sections.heading: 4. Preprocessing for Extracting Information for Queries
sections.text: In this section, we describe a way of pre-processing the queried ontology to extract information useful for arranging the axiom templates in a query. This pre-processing is useful for axiom templates of the form c1 (t), r1 (t, t), or t ≈ t ², where c1 is a concept term, r1 a role term, and t, t ² are individual terms.

sections.heading: 4.1 Extracting Individual Information from Reasoner Models
4.1.1 Individual Clustering
sections.text: In this section we describe the procedure for creating clusters of individuals within an ontology O using a constructed precursor An of O. Two types of clusters are created: concept clusters and role clusters. Concept clusters contain individuals with the same concepts in their label and role clusters. Let O have an ontology and An a precursor for O. We define the following two relationships P1 and P2, which represent an individual a from O to the roles for which an individual has at least one successor or predecessor: P1 (a) = {r | r | LAn (< a, b >) an ontology and a precursor for O. sections.heading: 5. Query Answering and Axiom Template Ordering
sections.text: In this section we describe two different algorithms (one static and one dynamic) for the arrangement of the axiom templates of a quantum theory that is based on some costs, and then we deal with the formulation of these costs. First, we present the abstract representation of a quantum theory on which we define the calculated statistical costs.

sections.heading: 6. Complex Axiom Template Optimizations
sections.text: In this section, we will first describe some optimizations we have developed for complex axiom templates (Section 6.1, 6.2) and then introduce the method for evaluating queries (Section 6.3).

More complex WHERE clauses, which use operators such as UNION for alternative selection criteria or OPTIONAL to query for optional bindings (Prud’hommeaux & Seaborne, 2008), can be evaluated simply by combining the results obtained by the BGP evaluation. Similarly, operations such as the projection of variables from the SELECT clause is a straightforward operation over the results of the evaluation of the WHERE clause. Therefore, we focus here on BGP evaluation only. metadata.abstractText: The SPARQL query language is currently being extended by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) with so-called entailment regimes. An entailment regime defines how queries are evaluated under more expressive semantics than SPARQL’s standard simple entailment, which is based on subgraph matching. The queries are very expressive since variables can occur within complex concepts and can also bind to concept or role names. In this paper, we describe a sound and complete algorithm for the OWL Direct Semantics entailment regime. We further propose several novel optimizations such as strategies for determining a good query execution order, query rewriting techniques, and show how specialized OWL reasoning tasks and the concept and role hierarchy can be used to reduce the query execution time. For determining a good execution order, we propose a cost-based model, where the costs are based on information about the instances of concepts and roles that are extracted from a model abstraction built by an OWL reasoner. We present two ordering strategies: a static and a dynamic one. For the dynamic case, we improve the performance by exploiting an individual clustering approach that allows for computing the cost functions based on one individual sample from a cluster. We provide a prototypical implementation and evaluate the efficiency of the proposed optimizations. Our experimental study shows that the static ordering usually outperforms the dynamic one when accurate statistics are available. This changes, however, when the statistics are less accurate, e.g., due to nondeterministic reasoning decisions. For queries that go beyond conjunctive instance queries we observe an improvement of up to three orders of magnitude due to the proposed optimizations.
